captions.text:
Last month I visited a body farm in Texas.
So these are places where researchers take

recently deceased human bodies and they essentially
just leave them out to decompose. So this

research, mainly it's helpful when law enforcement
come across a body under mysterious circumstances,

maybe a murder, and they want to know how
long has it been out here. The bodies are

scattered all over the field. They have about
50 out and most of them are under these metal

cages that prevent the vultures from getting
in. I kept asking him to lift up the cages

for me to get better photos. So what happens
right after you die is all the fluids that

are inside your cells when you're alive leak
out and bacteria start feeding immediately.

There converting the liquids and solids inside
you into gasses that they emit, and this causes

the second stage, which is bloat. You also
have something called marbling during this

stage because one of the gases, sulfur, binds
to the hemoglobin molecules in your blood

and changes the color of them to an orange
or yellow. And at the same time, flies come.

They come almost immediately when the body
is placed, and they lay eggs. And they especially

lay them in any orifices, so your head will
get a lot of maggots on it -- the eye sockets

and mouth and nose, and they'll eat away at
that first. They're absolutely just crawling

all over the body, like, getting up really
close to it and taking photos was the most

intense thing I did there. Then after a few
days of that, the body moves to the third

stage, which is called purge. And that's ultimately
the bloating is relieved as a lot of the gas

and fluids leak out and you see this dark
fluid pooling around the body. And the interesting

thing is that fluid is really nutrient rich,
but it's so rich in nitrogen that it kills

off the plants initially. But a year later,
it'll become especially fertile. So here this

is the next stage. A lot of the changes happen
really rapidly at first, and then it slows

down a lot. There's certainly still bacteria
here, but if you were to graph all the nutrients,

it's a very sharp decline. If the body is
in the sun, especially in Texas, the heat

is so strong that a lot of bacteria and insects
can't actually survive. And so instead of

continuing to decompose the body, it will
really gradually mummify -- it'll just dry

up. But if the body is in the shade, then
the bacteria and insects can continue to feed

on it and they'll essentially eat it down
to a skeleton. With the vultures, the process

is completely different because a flock of
them will just swarm a body immediately if

it's left uncaged, and they can eat pretty
much all of the flesh off within a few hours.

One of the things that really fascinated me
is the way that the bones are frayed. And

that's from their beaks ripping at it voraciously.
And that looks like leather or clothing, but

it's skin. Typically they're left out to decompose
for 6 to 12 months. So when the bodies come

in, they'll boil them and they put detergent
on them and that strips away most of the remaining

flesh. And then volunteer undergraduate interns
will clean every single bone with a toothbrush.

The smell was actually the strongest inside
that lab. It smells like rotting meat, which

is essentially what it is -- you know, just
organic substances that have gone bad. And

then after they get clean they get laid back
out, they get labeled, and then they get sent

to the lab closer into town where they get
boxed up. And so this basically serves as

a contemporary skeleton collection, which
there aren't that many of, as it turns out.

We really seldom see bodies anymore in our
modern culture. Most people die in a hospital.

They get directly sent to a funeral home.
That funeral home injects them with formaldehyde

and puts makeup all over them, so they don't
look like a dead body. But the truth is that

ultimately, whether we see it or not, this
happens. Unless you get cremated, it's going

to happen to you. I mean, that's what ecosystems
evolved to do -- is harvest nutrients
to create new life.

title: The fascinating process of human decomposition

comments.author: Big Nope

comments.text:
Seriously... I would not want to rot. Its better off to be burned. Or your 
body being frozen (if there is such method). Or like the ancient Egyptians 
did: they used to wrap a dead body in lots and lots of layers of material 
and put it into a golden coffin. That way no isnects and oxygen would be 
able to enter which could cause the body to decay. Today scientists have 
opened up many ancient Egyptian coffins with bodys being over 3000-5000 
thousand years old and completely undecayed. But once the coffins are 
opened up and the bodys unwraped the the bodys would last undecayed only 
for about 10 seconds and then they would instantly turn into dust with 
leaving only the skeleton.﻿

comments.text:
Look people, this is where we all are going to end up. This is what we are 
all eventually going to look like no matter how beautiful we think we are. 
This is our final resting place no matter how big of a mansion we used to 
live in.
Yes friends , this will be the end for all of us, rich, poor, black, white, 
tall, short, man, woman, attractive, unattractive, the finale of life is 
the same. Death is indeed the greatest equalizer.
So take heed , when you know that this will be your end some day, how can 
you be so arrogant? how can you be so selfish? how can you be so 
indifferent to pain and suffering of others? how can it be easy for you to 
hurt others? What do you really have that you are bragging about so much? 
What have you done to better the life of a single creature?
Yes this is the end. The lowest of the low, the ugliest of the ugly. So try 
to look beyond that body of yours that is destined to look like this. Try 
to have some humanity, because it is your humanity and the consequences of 
your actions that will never decompose or decay. Salute. ﻿

comments.author: TheWarpReaver

comments.text:
+Brooke G FYI, the majority of organs are only harvested when the person is 
pronounced with a brain death, which is very different from biological 
death.

The brain must have zero metabolic activity, but the body must be able to 
sustain its own life (that is, if machines can pump the air into the lungs 
{since the respiratory drive has gone to shit} and, though a tube, they can 
feed the person by offering food directly to the stomach or give the person 
a parenteral nutrition). THEN the body is continuously pumped with some 
drugs to prep the organs for donation, minimizing tissue damage. I love the 
fact that the heart has a self-stimulizing region (sinoatrial node), so it 
can pump blood without brain commands (though brain commands do alter the 
frequency/strength of the contractions).

Now, go forth and read about "locked in syndrome".

Happy nightmares.
